bibl.author: William Sloane Kennedy
bibl.title: William Sloane Kennedy to Walt Whitman, 27 December 1889
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: On the back of this letter from Kennedy, Whitman wrote a letter to the Canadian physician Richard Maurice Bucke that was dated February 2–3, 1889.

revisionDesc.change: first check, corrected, adjusted multitext encoding

body.p: What does this mean—this solemn cemetery business? And yet it is well. It has a solemn-tragic, solid magnificent resoluteness—a kind of secular range of vision—one might expect fr. Walt Whitman. Down then, climbing sorrow! & let us have it over with. & pass on to hope that the burial business wont be mentioned again for many years. Dont get down-hearted, my boy, say I! We read yr strong verse in November Century. Mrs K & I think yr poems in old age are just as fine as any of the others—softly suffused with an after-glow flush—dream-like & pensive. I'm afraid a kind of grip has got hold of you this weather! Merry Xmas, dear Walt!

postscript.p: Am reading the Century Life of Lincoln in back numbers.
